Award.AwardTitle: Mathematics and Science Education Enrollment and Development (MSEED) Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, called MSEED, is increasing the number of STEM graduates in Northwest Indiana. Students earn a bachelor's degree in science or mathematics, as well as teacher licensure within four years. They participate in a significant undergraduate research component, curriculum development training, faculty mentoring and an immersive teaching experience in diverse communities. These strategies are designed to improve retention and to produce effective teachers who possess a firm understanding of the scientific method. High quality math and science teaching is an important factor in increasing student achievement and promoting career exploration in STEM fields.

The program recruits from and interacts with high-need and high-poverty areas of Northwest Indiana. MSEED graduates are professional educators who effectively teach and motivate students. It is expected that each of these teachers will have a positive influence on 150 secondary students each year. Project activities are assessed for efficacy as well as a longitudinal study of the future high school teachers' effectiveness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2011-2018, the Valparaiso University (VU) Mathematics and Science Education Enrollment and Development (MSEED) program aimed to address directly and indirectly America’s growing need for students trained in the mathematics and science (M&S) fields by enrolling at least 75 students, who would graduate from VU while earning both a B.S. degree in a STEM field and teacher licensure. Since high-quality M&S teaching is the single most important factor in improving student achievement in these fields (Business-Higher Education Forum, 2008), we designed the MSEED program to produce STEM graduates, who are well-trained M&S teachers that are able to work effectively with a diverse population of students, thereby attracting additional students to STEM. During the funded period, the MSEED program included several components for students selected as MSEED scholars, each of which has been shown by prior research to improve student performance in STEM or produce teachers that are more effective:

  • a summer undergraduate research experience to improve retention in STEM and grow content mastery;
  • a summer curriculum and pedagogy development project to develop differentiated instructional strategies that promote critical thinking, analysis, and reflection through formative and summative assessment; and
  • a compact immersion experience to foster an understanding of classroom diversity.

We proposed that these experiences, together with extensive mentoring and a well-defined 4-year curriculum, would increase the number and quality of students graduating from VU with a STEM and education double major. Importantly, since each MSEED graduate will interact with 100-150 students annually in his/her own middle or high school classroom, the broader impact of MSEED is that it increases the number of HQ M&S professional educators who have the potential to catalyze a dramatic increase in the number of individual who pursue STEM careers.

By the end of the funded period, the MSEED Program enrolled 86 VU students as MSEED Scholars in seven distinct cohort groups. For the first four cohort groups (n = 69 students) in which we have the most complete data (all of these students have completed at least four years of college), we observed a freshman-to-sophomore retention of 96%, a 4-year graduation rate of 70% (any major) and 5-year graduation rate of 83% (any major). In terms of STEM persistence, 52/69 (75%) completed successfully a STEM major and 56/69 (81%) completed a STEM major or minor despite the fact that only 61% completed a double major in a STEM field and education. Although we cannot conclude with certainty whether a singular factor or multiple factors are responsible for the high observed STEM graduation rate among these students, we note that 91% who participated in a summer undergraduate research experience (after their freshman or sophomore academic year) earned a degree in STEM. Moreover, based on the results of survey data, a majority of MSEED Scholars also noted the importance of the MSEED community in their decision to remain in the program or their academic majors. Anecdotally, many of the MSEED graduates (i.e. those students who are earned a B.S. degree in a STEM field and obtained teacher licensure), have cited the MSEED community as playing a key role in their persistence as middle- or high-school educators throughout NW Indiana and beyond. In fact, among the first three cohorts of MSEED graduates who have served at least one year as a M&S educator, 96% are still teaching and most remain in contact with the program and each other. Taken together, we believe these data strongly suggest that the MSEED program, together with its emphasis on building a lasting community, provides an exportable model for producing high quality M&S educators who will be retained in the teaching profession at a significantly higher rate than the national trend.  

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/03/2019
Modified by: Robert W Clark
